definition[0]: if someone in authority vetoes something, they refuse to allow it to happen, especially something that other people or organizations have agreed
example[0]: President Bush vetoed the bill on July 6.
definition[1]: to refuse to accept a particular plan or suggestion
example[1]: Jenny wanted to invite all her friends, but I quickly vetoed that idea.
definition[2]: a refusal to give official permission for something, or the right to refuse to give such permission
example[2]: The Senate had a sufficient majority to override the presidential veto  (=not accept his refusal).
example[3]: de Gaulle’s veto on the British application to join the EEC
example[4]: The head teacher has the right of veto over management-board decisions.
example[5]: Washington’s veto of Seoul’s nuclear ambitions
definition[3]: to officially refuse to allow something to happen, especially something other people have agreed
example[6]: An attempt to use £35 million to strengthen the bank’s capital was vetoed by bank regulators.
